metadata.name: Japanese Sentences
metadata.description: Ichidan verbs with counters, proper nouns, and culturally useful notes.

schema.label: Japanese
schema.description: Full Japanese sentence in natural surface form.

schema.label: English
schema.description: Natural English translation conveying overall meaning rather than literal structure.

schema.label: Notes
schema.description: Instance-only notes: sentence-specific nuance, context assumptions, naturalness warnings, or culture/pragmatics tied to this exact sentence. Do NOT restate general grammar rules (use `grammarNotes`) or general vocabulary definitions (use word entries).

schema.label: Grammar Notes
schema.description: High-value grammar recognition notes and common contrast pairs relevant to patterns appearing in this sentence. Prefer short disambiguation insights that help learners distinguish easily confused structures (e.g., Vてきた vs Vていく, ので vs から). Avoid sentence-specific nuance or long theoretical explanations; those belong in `notes`.

schema.label: Chunks
schema.description: Ordered learner-optimized reading units composing the sentence. Each chunk may contain its own focus and references.

sentenceChunk.description: A learner reading unit inside a sentence. Every chunk must link to at least one non-particle reference (content word or grammar pattern). Do not include particles in refs.

fields.label: Chunk Japanese
fields.description: Japanese surface text for this chunk exactly as it appears in the sentence.

fields.label: Gloss
fields.description: Short learner-friendly meaning/paraphrase for this chunk.

fields.label: Grammar Focus
fields.description: Canonical grammar/pattern label if this chunk targets a structure (e.g., 'AながらB', 'Vていく').

fields.label: References
fields.description: REQUIRED, NON-EMPTY. Must include at least one lookup key for a content word or grammar pattern used in this chunk. Do NOT include particles (は/が/を/に/で/と/へ/も/や/の/ね/よ/か etc.). Authoring rule: do not create particle-only chunks; attach particles to an adjacent chunk that contains a referencable item.

entries.ja: フーディーニは三回も冷たい水を浴びた。
entries.en: Houdini even bathed in cold water three times.
grammarNotes: 回 is a general counter for occurrences/actions.

chunks.ja: フーディーニは三回も

notes: Houdini is famous for extreme escape and endurance feats; 三回も adds surprise/emphasis (“as many as three times”).

entries.ja: 駅で友だちを二人迎えました。
entries.en: I welcomed two friends at the station.
grammarNotes: 人 is the counter for people (二人 = two people).
notes: 迎える is commonly used for meeting someone at a station/airport, not just greeting verbally.

entries.ja: 先生は三つの質問に答えた。
entries.en: The teacher answered three questions.
grammarNotes: つ is a general counter used for small quantities or when the specific counter is unknown.
notes: Japanese often omits the subject; here it is explicit for learning clarity.

entries.ja: 彼は概要を一ページで伝えた。
entries.en: He conveyed the summary in one page.
grammarNotes: ページ is a counter for pages/documents.

chunks.ja: 彼は概要を一ページで
chunks.gloss: he in one page the summary

notes: Japanese business communication often values concise summaries (概要) over long explanations.

entries.ja: 私は二分で住所を調べた。
entries.en: I looked up the address in two minutes.
grammarNotes: 分 is the counter for minutes when expressing duration.
notes: で after a time span marks the time required to complete an action.

entries.ja: このプリンとあのプリンを二個比べた。
entries.en: I compared these two puddings.
grammarNotes: 個 is a general counter for small objects.

chunks.ja: このプリンとあのプリンを二個

notes: プリン in Japan usually refers to custard pudding (flan-like), not gelatin dessert.

entries.ja: 彼は三枚の写真を見せた。
entries.en: He showed three photos.
grammarNotes: 枚 is the counter for flat objects (paper, photos, tickets).
notes: 見せる implies showing something to someone; the recipient is often omitted if obvious.

entries.ja: 会議の時間を一時間に決めた。
entries.en: We decided the meeting time to be one hour.
grammarNotes: 時間 is a counter for hours when expressing duration.

chunks.ja: 会議の時間を一時間に
chunks.gloss: the meeting time to one hour

notes: Japanese often omits “we”; the subject is inferred from context.

entries.ja: 彼は三日で研究を始めた。
entries.en: He started the research in three days.
grammarNotes: 日 is the counter for days when expressing time span.
notes: 三日で implies the preparation period before starting, not the duration of the research itself.

entries.ja: 彼女は二本の説明を終えた。
entries.en: She finished two explanations.
grammarNotes: 本 is a counter for long cylindrical items, but also used metaphorically for speeches/presentations.
notes: Using 本 for talks/presentations is metaphorical; learners often expect 回 instead.

entries.ja: 彼はフリーズを五秒続けた。
entries.en: He kept the freeze for five seconds.
grammarNotes: 秒 is the counter for seconds.
notes: フリーズ is a loanword used in gaming/dance contexts to mean “hold still.”

entries.ja: 先生は二点の努力を認めた。
entries.en: The teacher acknowledged two points of effort.
grammarNotes: 点 is a counter for points/items in lists or evaluations.

chunks.gloss: the teacher two points of effort

notes: 点 is common in grading or evaluations; it does not always mean physical ‘points.’

entries.ja: 彼女はプテラノドンの模型を一体褒めた。
entries.en: She praised one pteranodon model.
grammarNotes: 体 is a counter for large animals or statues/models of living beings.

chunks.ja: 彼女はプテラノドンの模型を一体

notes: 体 is also used for statues/figures of animals, not only living creatures.

entries.ja: 子どもは鬼をこわがっています。
entries.en: Children are afraid of demons.
grammarNotes: Vている here expresses a continuing state (being afraid), not an ongoing action.

entries.ja: 太郎は家の長男です。
entries.en: Tarō is the eldest son in the family.

chunks.gloss: is the eldest son of the family

entries.ja: 昔話には鬼がよく出てきます。
entries.en: Demons often appear in old folk tales.
grammarNotes: Vてくる often indicates something appearing/coming into existence from a narrative perspective.

entries.ja: 太郎は元気な子どもです。
entries.en: Tarō is an energetic child.

entries.ja: びっくりして目玉が大きくなった。
entries.en: My eyes widened in surprise.
grammarNotes: Vて links cause/reason to the following clause (because I was surprised...).
Vくなる expresses a change of state.

entries.ja: うちの親父は料理が好きです。
entries.en: My dad likes cooking.
notes: 親父 is colloquial and masculine; tone depends on context.

entries.ja: 彼は家の長男です。
entries.en: He is the eldest son in the family.

chunks.gloss: is the eldest son of the family

entries.ja: 長男なので、家をつぐ予定です。
entries.en: Because he is the eldest son, he plans to inherit the family.
grammarNotes: なので gives a softer explanatory reason than だから.

entries.ja: 長男は東京で働いています。
entries.en: The eldest son works in Tokyo.
grammarNotes: Vている indicates a continuing state (employment).

entries.ja: 河の近くで遊ばないでください。
entries.en: Please don't play near the river.
grammarNotes: Vないでください is a polite request not to do something.

entries.ja: 昔の童の話を読みました。
entries.en: I read an old story about children.

entries.ja: 河童は川に住むと言われています。
entries.en: Kappa are said said to live in rivers.
grammarNotes: と言われている expresses hearsay or commonly accepted belief.

entries.ja: 子どもに川へ近づかないように、河童の話をしました。
entries.en: We told kappa stories so children wouldn’t go near the river.
grammarNotes: Vないように expresses purpose/prevention ('so that not').

chunks.ja: 子どもに川へ近づかないように
chunks.gloss: so that children do not go near the river

entries.ja: 昔から河童の伝説が日本にあります。
entries.en: Kappa legends have existed in Japan since long ago.
grammarNotes: 昔から indicates continuation from the past until now.

chunks.ja: 河童の伝説が日本にあります

entries.ja: 森で狐を見ました。
entries.en: I saw a fox in the forest.

entries.ja: 妖狐は人に化けると言われています。
entries.en: Fox spirits are said to transform into humans.
grammarNotes: Vると言われている indicates commonly reported belief.

chunks.gloss: that fox spirits transform into people

entries.ja: 昔の話には狐の霊がよく出てきます。
entries.en: Fox spirits often appear in old stories.

entries.ja: 村の人は狐の霊を信じていました。
entries.en: The villagers believed in fox spirits.
grammarNotes: Vていた marks a past continuing state.

chunks.ja: 狐の霊を信じていました

entries.ja: 狐の霊が人に化けるという伝説があります。
entries.en: There is a legend that fox spirits transform into humans.
grammarNotes: という + noun labels or defines content ('the legend that...').

chunks.ja: 狐の霊が人に化けるという
chunks.gloss: that fox spirits transform into people

entries.ja: ハワイの海で三時間も泳いでいました。
entries.en: I was swimming in the ocean in Hawaii for three hours.
grammarNotes: Vていました = past progressive / ongoing action in the past.

chunks.gloss: for as long as three hours

entries.ja: 東京駅まで急がなければなりません。
entries.en: I have to hurry to Tokyo Station.
grammarNotes: Vなければなりません = formal obligation “must do”.

chunks.ja: 急がなければなりません

entries.ja: 家に入ったら、すぐコートを脱いでください。
entries.en: When you enter the house, please take off your coat right away.
grammarNotes: Vたら = conditional “when/if”.
Vてください = polite request.

chunks.ja: コートを脱いでください

entries.ja: このアプリはウイルスを防げます。
entries.en: This app can prevent viruses.
grammarNotes: Potential form (Vえる/られる) expresses ability.

entries.ja: 彼はニューヨークでたくさんお金を稼いだ。
entries.en: He earned a lot of money in New York.
grammarNotes: Plain past (Vた) indicates completed action.

chunks.ja: たくさんお金を稼いだ

entries.ja: 子供たちが夜遅くまで騒いでいる。
entries.en: The children are being noisy until late at night.
grammarNotes: Vている can express ongoing action or current state.

entries.ja: Wi-Fiにスマホを繋げば、地図が見られます。
entries.en: If you connect your phone to Wi-Fi, you can see the map.
grammarNotes: Vば = conditional “if/when”.

chunks.gloss: if you connect your phone to Wi-Fi

entries.ja: 彼女は京都のカフェでコーヒーを注いでいた。
entries.en: She was pouring coffee at a café in Kyoto.
grammarNotes: Vていた = past ongoing action.

chunks.ja: 彼女は京都のカフェで
chunks.gloss: she at a café in Kyoto

chunks.ja: コーヒーを注いでいた

entries.ja: 朝、包丁を研いでから料理を始めます。
entries.en: In the morning, I sharpen the knife and then start cooking.
grammarNotes: Vてから = do A and then B.

chunks.gloss: in the morning, after sharpening the knife

entries.ja: このシャツは手で濯いだほうがいい。
entries.en: It’s better to rinse this shirt by hand.
grammarNotes: Vたほうがいい = giving advice or recommendation.

chunks.ja: 手で濯いだほうがいい
chunks.gloss: it’s better to rinse by hand

entries.ja: 犬がバッグの中をずっと嗅いでいる。
entries.en: The dog keeps sniffing inside the bag.
grammarNotes: Vている often indicates continuous action.

entries.ja: 彼は毎朝プールで泳ぐ。
entries.en: He swims in the pool every morning.
grammarNotes: Frequency adverb 毎朝 commonly pairs with habitual present.

entries.ja: 人混みの中を泳ぐように進んだ。
entries.en: I pushed forward through the crowd as if swimming.
grammarNotes: Vるように = 'as if / in such a way that'.
notes: Figurative use of 泳ぐ for moving through a dense space.

entries.ja: 駅まで急いだ。
entries.en: I hurried to the station.

entries.ja: 宿題を急いで終わらせた。
entries.en: I hurried and finished my homework quickly.
grammarNotes: Vて = sequential action ('hurrying and then…').
notes: 終わらせる is transitive: 'finish (something)'.

entries.ja: 結論を急ぐべきではない。
entries.en: You shouldn't rush to a conclusion.
grammarNotes: Vるべきではない = 'should not'.

entries.ja: 靴を脱いでください。
entries.en: Please take off your shoes.
grammarNotes: Vてください = polite request.
notes: Common in homes, some restaurants, and certain indoor spaces.

entries.ja: りんごの皮を脱ぐ。
entries.en: Peel off an apple’s skin.
notes: This use exists but 皮をむく is more common for 'peel'.

entries.ja: 事故を防ぐために注意する。
entries.en: Be careful in order to prevent accidents.
grammarNotes: Vるために = 'in order to'.

entries.ja: 雨を防ぐコートを着る。
entries.en: I wear a coat that blocks the rain.
grammarNotes: Plain form + noun = noun modification.

entries.ja: 彼は会社でお金を稼いでいる。
entries.en: He earns money at his company.
grammarNotes: Vている can express ongoing state/habit.

entries.ja: 広告で時間を稼いだ。
entries.en: I bought time with an ad.
notes: Common in games/apps: watch an ad to get extra time/continues.

entries.ja: 子どもたちが外で騒いでいる。
entries.en: The kids are making noise outside.
grammarNotes: Vている = ongoing action.

entries.ja: そんなことで騒ぐな。
entries.en: Don’t make a fuss over something like that.
grammarNotes: Dictionary form + な = casual negative command.

entries.ja: 心が騒いで眠れなかった。
entries.en: My mind was unsettled and I couldn’t sleep.
grammarNotes: Vられる(neg) = inability (眠れない).

entries.ja: ケーブルを機械に繋ぐ。
entries.en: Connect the cable to the machine.

entries.ja: 過去と未来を繋ぐ物語。
entries.en: A story that connects the past and the future.
grammarNotes: Plain form + noun = noun modification.

entries.ja: 話題を繋いで時間を稼ぐ。
entries.en: Keep the conversation going and buy time.
grammarNotes: Vて = sequence/means ('by doing X, do Y').

entries.ja: コップに水を注ぐ。
entries.en: Pour water into a cup.

entries.ja: 研究に力を注ぐ。
entries.en: Devote energy to research.

entries.ja: 窓から光が注いでいる。
entries.en: Light is streaming in through the window.
grammarNotes: Vている = ongoing state (streaming).

entries.ja: 包丁を研ぐ。
entries.en: Sharpen a kitchen knife.

entries.ja: 技術を研ぐ。
entries.en: Hone your skills.

entries.ja: シャツを水で濯ぐ。
entries.en: Rinse a shirt with water.

entries.ja: 食後に口を濯ぐ。
entries.en: Rinse your mouth after a meal.
grammarNotes: 食後 = 'after eating' (set phrase).

entries.ja: 花の香りを嗅ぐ。
entries.en: Smell the scent of a flower.

entries.ja: 危険を嗅ぎつける。
entries.en: Sense danger (sniff it out).
grammarNotes: Vます-stem + つける often means 'do thoroughly / attach' → idiomatic compounds.
notes: 嗅ぎつける is an idiom: detect/sense something quickly.

entries.ja: 家業を継ぐ。
entries.en: Inherit the family business.

entries.ja: 父の後を継ぐ。
entries.en: Succeed my father (take over after him).
grammarNotes: 後を継ぐ is a set phrase for succession.

entries.ja: 伝統を継ぐ。
entries.en: Carry on a tradition.

entries.ja: 布を継いで使う。
entries.en: Patch cloth together and use it.
grammarNotes: Vて = means ('by patching, use it').

entries.ja: 穴を塞ぐ。
entries.en: Block up a hole.

entries.ja: 耳を塞ぐ。
entries.en: Cover your ears.

entries.ja: 道を塞ぐ。
entries.en: Block the road.

entries.ja: 悲しくて胸が塞いだ。
entries.en: I was so sad that my chest felt heavy.
grammarNotes: くて = cause/reason (悲しくて…).
notes: 胸が塞ぐ is a common expression for emotional heaviness.

entries.ja: 米袋を担ぐ。
entries.en: Shoulder a sack of rice.

entries.ja: みんなに担がれた。
entries.en: Everyone was playing a prank on me.
grammarNotes: Passive Vられる can mark being subjected to an action.
notes: 担ぐ = 'to prank/hoax' in this colloquial sense.

entries.ja: 神輿を担ぐ。
entries.en: Carry a portable shrine (mikoshi).
notes: Mikoshi are carried in festivals; teams lift and chant together.

entries.ja: じゃがいもの皮を剥ぐ。
entries.en: Peel a potato.

entries.ja: 仮面を剥ぐ。
entries.en: Strip off the mask (reveal the truth).
notes: Often used figuratively: expose someone's true nature.

entries.ja: 空を仰ぐ。
entries.en: Look up at the sky.

entries.ja: 師を仰ぐ。
entries.en: Revere a mentor.
notes: Somewhat formal/literary compared to 尊敬する.

entries.ja: 医者の助けを仰ぐ。
entries.en: Seek a doctor's help.
grammarNotes: Nの + N links possession/association (医者の助け).

entries.ja: ボートを漕ぐ。
entries.en: Row a boat.

entries.ja: 自転車を漕ぐ。
entries.en: Pedal a bicycle.

entries.ja: 困難の中を漕いで進む。
entries.en: Push forward through difficulties.
grammarNotes: Nの中を = 'through/within' a situation.
notes: Figurative extension from rowing/pedaling.

entries.ja: 神社に金を貢ぐ。
entries.en: Offer money to a shrine.
notes: Often implies offering/supporting rather than ordinary 'donation' wording.

entries.ja: 彼にお金を貢いでいる。
entries.en: She’s financially supporting him (one-sidedly).
grammarNotes: Vている = ongoing situation/habit.
notes: This sense often carries a negative nuance (being taken advantage of).

entries.ja: 糸を紡ぐ。
entries.en: Spin thread.

entries.ja: 言葉を紡いで語る。
entries.en: Weave words and speak.
grammarNotes: Vて = means ('by weaving words, speak').
notes: Literary feel; common in writing about storytelling.

entries.ja: 人生を紡ぐ。
entries.en: Build a life over time.
notes: Metaphorical; sounds poetic.

entries.ja: 木の表面を削ぐ。
entries.en: Shave off the surface of the wood.

entries.ja: やる気を削ぐ発言。
entries.en: A remark that kills motivation.
grammarNotes: Plain form + noun = noun modification (削ぐ発言).
notes: Common collocation: やる気を削ぐ = demotivate someone.

entries.ja: 庭で蜂を見たので、窓を閉めました。
entries.en: I saw a bee in the yard, so I closed the window.
notes: Uses ので for a neutral, explanatory “because,” fitting for giving a reason without sounding accusatory.
grammarNotes: ので is a softer, explanatory “because” than から and often sounds more neutral/polite.

chunks.gloss: because I saw a bee in the yard,

entries.ja: 夏は蜂が多いから、甘い飲み物に気をつけて。
entries.en: There are lots of bees in summer, so be careful with sweet drinks.
notes: A casual warning; 気をつけて sounds natural in conversation.
grammarNotes: から gives a straightforward reason; it can sound more direct than ので.
気をつけて is a common casual imperative meaning “be careful.”

chunks.gloss: because there are many bees in summer,

entries.ja: その花には蜜蜂がたくさん集まっています。
entries.en: Many honeybees are gathering on that flower.
notes: には highlights the location/target where honeybees gather (on/around the flower).
grammarNotes: Vている can describe an ongoing state/result (here: “are gathering/clustered”).

entries.ja: 蜜蜂は花粉を運ぶので、農業にも大切です。
entries.en: Honeybees carry pollen, so they are important for agriculture too.
notes: も emphasizes “also/too,” adding agriculture as another relevant domain.
grammarNotes: ので is a neutral explanatory “because.”
にも adds “also/too” to a target (here: agriculture).

chunks.ja: 蜜蜂は花粉を運ぶので、

entries.ja: のどが痛いとき、温かいお茶に蜂蜜を入れます。
entries.en: When my throat hurts, I add honey to warm tea.
notes: A common home remedy context: honey in warm tea for a sore throat.
grammarNotes: とき means “when” (time/occasion) and can set a general situation.

entries.ja: ヨーグルトに蜂蜜をかけると食べやすいです。
entries.en: If you drizzle honey on yogurt, it’s easier to eat.
notes: A practical, everyday tip; 食べやすい expresses ease/comfort in eating.
grammarNotes: Vると can express a natural result: “when/if you do X, Y happens.”
やすい attaches to a verb stem to mean “easy to do” (食べやすい).

chunks.ja: ヨーグルトに蜂蜜をかけると
chunks.gloss: if you drizzle honey on yogurt,

entries.ja: 山で雀蜂を見かけたら、走らずに静かに離れてください。
entries.en: If you spot a hornet in the mountains, please don’t run—quietly move away.
notes: Safety instruction tone: 〜てください is polite and appropriate for guidance.
grammarNotes: Vたら is a common conditional for “if/when.”
〜ずに means “without doing” (走らずに = without running).

chunks.ja: 山で雀蜂を見かけたら、
chunks.gloss: if you spot a hornet in the mountains,

chunks.ja: 静かに離れてください。

entries.ja: 雀蜂は危ないので、巣を見つけたら市役所に連絡します。
entries.en: Hornets are dangerous, so if I find a nest, I contact city hall.
notes: 市役所 (city hall) is a realistic contact point in Japan for reporting hazards like nests.
grammarNotes: ので is an explanatory “because.”
Vたら is a common “if/when” conditional.

entries.ja: ベランダに蜂の巣ができていて、びっくりしました。
entries.en: There was a wasp nest on the balcony, and I was surprised.
notes: できている describes an established state: the nest has formed and exists there now.
grammarNotes: Vている can describe a resulting state (できている = has formed/is there).
〜ていて can connect clauses with a causal/scene-setting feel.

chunks.ja: ベランダに蜂の巣ができていて、
chunks.gloss: there being a wasp nest on the balcony,

entries.ja: 蜂の巣が近いと危ないから、子どもには近づかないように言った。
entries.en: Because a nest nearby is dangerous, I told the kids not to go near it.
notes: 近づかないように言った is a common way to report giving a caution/instruction.
grammarNotes: Aと expresses a general condition: “if/when A, then (it is) B.”
〜ないように言う means “tell someone not to do” (caution/instruction).
から gives a direct reason.

chunks.ja: 蜂の巣が近いと危ないから、
chunks.gloss: because it’s dangerous if a nest is nearby,

chunks.ja: 近づかないように言った。
chunks.gloss: I told them not to go near it.

entries.ja: 田中さんは東京で新しい仕事を掴んだ。
entries.en: Mr. Tanaka secured a new job in Tokyo.
grammarNotes: で marks the location where something happens.

entries.ja: 山田さんは進路について悩んでいる。
entries.en: Ms. Yamada is worrying about her future path.
grammarNotes: Vている shows an ongoing state or action.

chunks.ja: 山田さんは進路について
chunks.gloss: Ms. Yamada about her future path

entries.ja: 大阪のカフェでコーヒーを頼んだ。
entries.en: I ordered coffee at a café in Osaka.

entries.ja: ノートの字が雨で滲んだ。
entries.en: The writing in the notebook smudged because of the rain.

entries.ja: 鈴木さんは毎朝お茶を飲む。
entries.en: Mr. Suzuki drinks tea every morning.

entries.ja: 昨日から頭が少し痛む。
entries.en: My head has been hurting a little since yesterday.
grammarNotes: から marks the starting point in time.

entries.ja: 佐藤さんは箱を車に積んだ。
entries.en: Mr. Sato loaded the boxes into the car.

entries.ja: 古いテーブルが少し歪んでいる。
entries.en: The old table is slightly warped.
grammarNotes: Vている can describe a resulting state.

entries.ja: 彼は昔の失敗を悔む。
entries.en: He regrets his past mistakes.

entries.ja: このセーターは洗うと縮む。
entries.en: This sweater shrinks when washed.
grammarNotes: と can express a natural result or general truth.

entries.ja: 京都で起きた事故を多くの人が悔やんだ。
entries.en: Many people mourned the accident that happened in Kyoto.

chunks.gloss: the accident that happened in Kyoto

entries.ja: 中村さんは福岡に住んでいる。
entries.en: Mr. Nakamura lives in Fukuoka.

entries.ja: 二人でチームを組んだ。
entries.en: The two of us formed a team.
grammarNotes: 二人 is the counter for two people.

entries.ja: 午後になって雨が止んだ。
entries.en: The rain stopped in the afternoon.

entries.ja: 町の人々は有名な作家の死を悼んだ。
entries.en: The townspeople mourned the death of the famous writer.

chunks.ja: 有名な作家の死を悼んだ

entries.ja: 北海道は自然に富んでいる。
entries.en: Hokkaido is rich in nature.
grammarNotes: に富む means “to be rich in / abound in.”

entries.ja: 彼は質問に答えず、口を噤んだ。
entries.en: He didn’t answer the question and fell silent.
grammarNotes: ず is a formal negative connective meaning “without doing.”

entries.ja: 田村さんは甘い物を慎んでいる。
entries.en: Mr. Tamura is refraining from sweets.

entries.ja: 山口さんは小さな店を営んでいる。
entries.en: Mr. Yamaguchi runs a small shop.

chunks.ja: 山口さんは小さな店を

entries.ja: 彼は昔の上司を今でも恨んでいる。
entries.en: He still resents his former boss.

entries.ja: 先生は学生をじっと睨んだ。
entries.en: The teacher stared intensely at the student.

entries.ja: 健太くんは図書館で本を読む。
entries.en: Kenta reads books at the library.

entries.ja: 母はプレゼントをきれいな紙で包んだ。
entries.en: My mother wrapped the present in pretty paper.

entries.ja: 祖母は冬になるとマフラーを編む。
entries.en: My grandmother knits scarves when winter comes.
grammarNotes: と can express a habitual or natural occurrence.

entries.ja: 上野動物園でパンダの赤ちゃんが生まれた。
entries.en: A baby panda was born at Ueno Zoo.
notes: 生まれる is the intransitive counterpart of 生む.

chunks.ja: パンダの赤ちゃんが生まれた

entries.ja: 日曜日は家でゆっくり休む。
entries.en: I rest slowly at home on Sundays.

entries.ja: このバナナはもう傷んでいる。
entries.en: This banana has already gone bad.

entries.ja: 試験に落ちて、彼はしょげている。
entries.en: He failed the exam and is feeling down.
notes: しょげる is the standard modern form meaning to feel dejected.

entries.ja: 彼女は海外で働くことを望んでいる。
entries.en: She hopes to work abroad.

chunks.ja: 彼女は海外で働くことを

entries.ja: 駅で誰かの足を踏んでしまった。
entries.en: I accidentally stepped on someone's foot at the station.
grammarNotes: Vてしまう often expresses regret or accidental completion.
